q: What are the symptoms of asbestosis?
a: Symptoms of asbestosis include shortness of breath, persistent cough, wheezing, extreme tiredness (fatigue), pain in your chest or shoulder, and clubbed (swollen) fingertips in more advanced cases.

q: What are the causes of asbestosis?
a: Asbestosis is caused by exposure to asbestos. Industries such as building or construction, particularly from the 1950s to the 1990s, have a higher risk of exposure. Certain roles in old buildings today can also lead to asbestos exposure, such as heating and ventilation engineers, demolition workers, plumbers, construction workers, and electricians.

q: When should I see a doctor if I think I have asbestosis?
a: You should see a GP if you have symptoms of asbestosis and think you've been exposed to asbestos.

q: What tests are done for diagnosing asbestosis?
a: A GP may listen to your lungs and ask about your work history. They may also refer you to a specialist in lung diseases for more tests. These tests may include a chest X-ray, a CT scan of the lungs, and lung function tests.

q: Is there a cure for asbestosis?
a: There is no cure for asbestosis once it has developed, as the damage to the lungs cannot be reversed. However, treatments such as pulmonary rehabilitation and oxygen therapy can help manage symptoms.

q: What can I do to help with asbestosis?
a: If you have asbestosis, you can try quitting smoking, as it can worsen your symptoms and increase the risk of lung cancer. It is also recommended to get the flu and pneumococcal vaccinations to reduce the chance of lung infections.

q: Where can I find information about the government compensation scheme for asbestosis?
a: You can find information about the government compensation scheme for asbestosis and check your eligibility for the industrial injuries disablement benefit on the GOV.UK website. Additionally, the Asthma and Lung UK website provides advice on benefits and compensation.

q: Can treatment improve the symptoms of asbestosis?
a: While there is no cure for asbestosis, treatment can help improve the symptoms. Treatments such as pulmonary rehabilitation, oxygen therapy, and the use of inhalers for mild symptoms can be beneficial.

q: How long does it take for symptoms of asbestosis to appear after exposure to asbestos?
a: It can take 20 to 30 years after being exposed to asbestos before symptoms of asbestosis appear. However, in some cases, there may be no symptoms at all.

a: It is recommended to quit smoking if you have asbestosis because smoking can worsen your symptoms and increase the risk of lung cancer.
